nodes.bodyText:
Nit: The Hive style guidelines require a period at the end of the first sentence here.
Please provide an example and provide some additional context... something like...
This output format matches the same format as a Hive table created with JSONFILE file format:

CREATE TABLE ... STORED AS JSONFILE;

Then provide a sample output in the JavaDoc.  Feel free to use HTML tags and JavaDoc docs to format and enhance.

nodes.bodyText:
Typically you want to flush the object to the underlying stream (ByteArrayOutputStream in this case) in case the object is doing any kind of internal buffering in order to "flush" its content out.
While your beeLine.output is technically correct.  It's a bit confusing to other coders.
Order of operations should be:

Flush the generator to clear any buffering into the target OutputStream
Convert the OutputStream into the target output format (String in this situation)
Please use a new String() with UTF-8 encoding explicitly specified here

https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/String.html#String-byte:A-java.nio.charset.Charset-
Nit: formatting issue

Take a look at using Boolean#parse instead:
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/Boolean.html#parseBoolean-java.lang.String-

Check out StandardCharsets.UTF_8.  It's not a requirement that all JVMs support UTF-8.
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/nio/charset/StandardCharsets.html

The Javadocs for ByteArrayOutputStream.toString(String charsetName)[1] point to this charset page.
Which says that "UTF-8" as the correct canonical name for the StandardCharset. I think my implementation is correct for all JVM's?
[1] https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/ByteArrayOutputStream.html
For clarities sake I'm changing this line to String out = ((ByteArrayOutputStream) generator.getOutputTarget()).toString(StandardCharsets.UTF_8.name());
OK.  I see what you're saying.  The JDK folks have not gotten around to adding the method to accept a discrete Charset yet.  Please do use the .name() call.
Yup overthought that one, fixed 👍
Need a type for BINARY data.  Make it spit it out as Base-64 to be text-friendly.

Thinking this through more Arrays.toString(byte[] a) will convert it to some string that looks like [16, 34, 67], meaning the resulting JSON will be {..."binary_field":"[16,34,67]"...}.
JSONOutputFormat does not have access to the underlying resultset, just the values that have already been toString()ed. Is the correct behavior then to convert back to byte[] and then Base64.encode()?
Ya, this is not a particularly helpful format.  The default in JSON is Base64 for binary data, so you should use that and not rely on this default
https://fasterxml.github.io/jackson-core/javadoc/2.8/com/fasterxml/jackson/core/JsonGenerator.html#writeBinary(byte[])

OK.  I follow now.  Sorry I didn't read your comment close enough. :)
So, I think for now, what you should so is...
Create a new case for BINARY data and then check that that this is set to "true".  Throw an Exception otherwise.
beeLine.getOpts().getConvertBinaryArrayToString();

At least this way, we can have a separate ticket about making this base-64 instead of the current implementation.  Then, just use writeString.
If Google Guava is included, use the Precondition class to check
Please clear the ByteArrayInputStream here otherwise it will carry around all the buffered data for a while.

Let's make this a bit more JUNIT-ish.
Please use the @BeforeClass annotation on the setupMockData() instead of calling like this manually

Please just use Mockito to capture the argument instead of making a mock manually like this.
https://www.baeldung.com/mockito-void-methods
